comment.author: 95609303@N00
comment._content: Sorry, but I do not understand the need to title the photo by what is marked on the photo itself. The photo stands by itself and there is no need to carry the offensive abbreviation to the title. The title of the photo cannot be excused by the claim that it merely reflects what is written on the photo itself, as the choice of title is the free choice of the poster, the Library of Congress, and as such reflects the Library of Congress' own voice. Is it not the Library of Congress' own voice when titling a photo that contains no textual markings? Does it not reflect the best judgment of the Library of Congress regarding the presumed factual (and not editorial) content of the photo? And what if extensive study shows that there exists photos in the collection that is marked in error with incorrect information? Would you in fact title the photo with the incorrect information? I suspect not, as it would be assumed that unless otherwise explicitly stated that the title is written in the voice of the Library of Congress. And are your methods such that any offensive comment written on a photo in your archives will also carry the same title on Flickr? And what is one to make of this photo, where a selective correction to the hand-written note was made when composing its title? Perhaps there can be a reasonable compromise. There exists photos in your collection that makes a clear distinction between the Library of Congress' voice and that of whoever annotated the photo, with square brackets used to mark the poster's (Library of Congress') voice. Perhaps that could be used in this case. e.g.: "[Japanese] typhoon-boats washed a mile inland at Tokyo (LOC)" Please reconsider retitling this photo. To use such racially loaded and derogatory abbreviations in an area that many would interpret as the Library of Congress' own voice is a very unwise choice and is not fitting the character of such a fine institution. Though I have not viewed all of your photos I have browsed through many of them and nowhere else do I see a similar offense committed. This is a bad precedent to set and is all the more unusual and provocative in its uniqueness with respect to the rest of your collection.

comment.author: 29056926@N02
comment._content:
@cgfan: LC should probably retitle with brackets as you suggest to simply avoid the debate.  It's historically significant that over the life of the boot black photo, some librarian at LC has mapped "Jew" to "Jewish" (possibly taking offense?), but the same hasn't happened for this photo.  Taking the abberviation out of the limelight of the index title, and storing it in a longer descriptive entry seems like the right move now.  Editing this stuff is a slippery slope, but to my ears "Jew" is more legit than "Jap".

Contrary to your claim, though, there are textual markings on the photo.  The text ("titling" as you refer to it alternately) was scrawled on by an observer of the events (photographer), which makes it primary source material and just as legitimate historic evidence as the photo itself.  What if a researcher is tracking the history of the use of the phrase "Jap"?  Erasing it from the digital database will simply hide the widespread nature of this term, and perhaps its start as an innocuous abbreviation for a long word.  This photo is almost three decades before the climax of the racist term.  It needs to be accessible somewhere.

comment.author: 8623220@N02
comment._content: Your comments gave us good food for thought! Expanding an abbreviated word in a title to clarify a spelling can be helpful, so we’ve added the fuller spelling in brackets. But this kind of bracketed interpolation is not intended to replace original vocabulary even when a word can cause offense. Quoting an original title is part of preserving historical context by reflecting how an item presented itself when first produced. Just as the Library doesn’t re-title books or movies, we don’t re-title pictures that come to us with formal titles. The unbracketed titles that appear with Library of Congress images in Flickr are not the Library’s own voice. The titles are transcriptions of original text found with the historical photographs. If putting “(LOC)” at the ends of the titles is creating the impression that the Library is writing a new title, we need to rethink adding that indication of where the photo is from. (When a photograph lacks an original title, then a note is provided “Title devised by Library staff” and brackets appear around the entire title. There are also judgment calls when, for example, only a surname or multiple abbreviated words appear on a photo. In those cases, the photo may have been given a quick annotation rather than a formal title, and a descriptive title might be devised with an explanatory note about the title source.) Your comments are helpful for seeing that in the complicated situation with the Bain negatives, where there are multiple sources of historical caption information (two sets of cards and the negatives themselves), varying the title source can cause confusion. Especially when our source of title notes ambiguously cite multiple sources as: “Title from unverified data provided by the Bain News Service on the negatives or caption cards.” We’d better stick with a single source-what can be seen in the negative. We’ve started by making sure that the titles for the photos mentioned in the comments above match what’s written on the negatives rather than the caption cards. FYI, the published standard that guides our practice in describing the variety of pictures we preserve is called "Graphic Materials: Rules for Describing Original Items and Historical Collections." It's available online at www.loc.gov/rr/print/gm/graphmat.html.
